Enore,
I want to second Gordon's advice. I would urge you not to alter you=
r  sword
in the way you are describing. If you want a grooved blade order o=
ne or
find one. At the very least you should not do anything until you have=
 had
your blade well shinsa'd.
Still, your question does point up a basic f=
eature of the world of
nippon-to. The values and standards of the various p=
eople involved in
Japanese swords are diverse. What is absolutely "wrong" t=
o some is "just
fine" to others. Most of us base our actions on our views o=
f aesthetics and
a sense of historical preservation. There are other values=
 out there and
knowing that helps to understand some of the things we see a=
bout swords.
When I was first in Japan I happened to meet a number of sword=
 craftsmen
rather than collectors. Of course this was interesting (heck, it=
 was
wonderful), but it may have given me a skewed view.
1. The first "smit=
h" I met ( and he was an important artist-and a
wonderful person) was re-te=
mpering some old swords when I visited his
forge.
2.  An important kinko pr=
oudly showed me his portfolio that included some
very excellent "umegane" w=
ork he had done. He assured me that "no one could
see" the fillings he had =
put into some seriously flawed blades.
3. During a road trip with a fellow =
who had recently completed his
polishing apprenticeship, we took a long ext=
ra trip to let his teacher see
the grooves he was carving on a tanto. He wa=
s proud of his work and his
master approved. When I asked why he was doing =
it, he said "the smith
should have put the grooves in."
These men are not c=
rooks or villains. Indeed, I think they are great
artists and skilled stude=
nts, but they operate with a different set of
values.
You certainly can fin=
d craftsmen who will do what you ask of them, but one
thing is clear. You w=
ill only be able to cut grooves in your sword once. I
urge you to proceed w=
ith caution.
Peter
